prompt: Write a poem about Gödel's incompleteness theorem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Topsy-Turvicle of Gödel’s Snare

’Twas Hilbert-time in Metamathe,
The axioms all aligned—  
All nimble were the Symbol-men,
With Lemmata well-inclined.

“Beware the Incompleteness-snark, my son!
That lurks within the book!
It leaves each Consistent-turtle stuck,
No Gödel-code forsook!

It slithers through the martingale of formal proofs so neat,
And with a self-referent twist it bites the rules it eats!”

He took his vorpal Gödel-wrench in hand:
Long time the Consis-doubt he sought—
So rested he by the ω-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in subtle self-thought stood,
The Incompleteness-snark,
Came huffing, puffing, loop-di-loop,
With recursion for its mark!

One, two! One, two! And Self-Swear through
The undecided claim!
He left it dead, theorem unfed,
Its negation just the same.

“And hast thou slain the system-wide?
Parade the Prince of Proof!
O frabjous day! Calloob, callay!”
He chortled in aloof.

’Twas Hilbert-time in Metamathe,
The axioms all askew—  
All shaky were the Symbol-men,
And no completeness true.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on shortest path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shortestwock Path
’Twas brillig, and the edge-weighted trees  
Did gyre and gimble in the graph;  
All mimsy were the dist-array pleas,  
To reach the non-overlapping path.  

“Beware the Cycle-baum, my son!  
The loops that trap, the bridges fall!  
Beware the Neg-weight jag and shun  
The frumious Bellman-Ford!”  

He took his Dijkstra-gram in hand:  
Long time the greedy search he sought—  
So rested he by the T-mum tree,  
And coded many a step and fraught.  

And, as in ughly heap he stood,  
The Shortestwock with path of flame  
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,  
And burbled as it came!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The vorpal edge went knicker-snack!  
He left it shortest—broke the queue—  
And went galumphing back.  

“And hast thou slain the Shortestwock?  
Come to my arms, my beamish knight!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled at the light.  

’Twas brillig, and the edge-weighted trees  
Did gyre and gimble in the graph;  
All mimsy were the dist-array pleas,  
To reach the non-overlapping path.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about suitcase in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Valisnatch Hauler-Song

’Twas zuggage-zung, the brindle-nite,
When grobbly tags and tampsties sig’t;
The porterwhalls, the carousel,
With whoofs aplenty durn their swell.

“Beware the Valisnatch, youngling skin!
The zip that snarks, the wheel that grins!
Beware the crump-lock clorpt—beware!
It gnatchles any footware!”

He took his whistly-grip in hand,
Long time the framd he shuffl-and;
Until he spied the brushened case—
Came woolens-vining back from space.

One knap! Two knaw! His clothespegs spread
As shirts went lapping overhead!
He left it jam-packed, life intact,
And whistled home with pockets sacked.

“So hast thou slain the Valisnatch?
Come quick, my boy, unknot the catch!”
He flung it wide—no socks inside—
Just postcards wearing worlds they’d tried.

’Twas zuggage-zung, the weary wheels,
Still earnest-humming travel feels;
And every dream-light tag aglow
Tells where the suitcase chose to go.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about hollow grind in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Hollow-Grind of Glimber Ghye  

’Twas brilly in the blade-bay, and the whetstone whirled did gyre,  
All slitty were the edges as the grinder sang his choir;  
Beware the Hollow-Grind, my boy, the thinness, keen, unkind—  
That blade beneath whose belly gleams the hollow-runnelled mind!  

He took his carbide talon-sword, he took his leather strop,  
And slithered through the spark-lit dark where clattering razors drop;  
He rested by the Tumtum wheel, and stood awhile in thought—  
Then came the Hollow-Grind, with whistles keenly wrought.  

One, two! One two! and through-and-through the whetted steel it flashed;  
The edge went snicker-snack, the void beneath it clashed;  
He left it thin, he left it bright, he left it curved and blind—  
And burbled back triumphant from the Hollow-Grind.  

“And hast thou carved the Hollow-Grind? Come to my arms, my beamish blade!  
O frabjous slice! Callooh! Callay!” He chortled in his glade.  
’Twas brilly in the blade-bay, and the whetstone whirled did gyre—  
Beware the Hollow-Grind, my joy, or kiss your fingers fire!
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on cedar chest in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cedrwock Chest

’Twas cedar-scented, gloaming’s chest,
With camphor claws and hummocks humous;
All cedar-clawed it creaked abreast,
And burbled through the dusk domus.

“Beware the Cedrwock, my child!
The scented jaw, the splintery grip!
Beware the moth-dust, vapour mild,
The cedar-clink that seals the lip!”

He took his padlock key in hand—
Long time the cedar gloom he sought—
Then rested by the camphor stand
And pondered moths in cedar-wrought.

And while in darkled dreams he stood,
The Cedrwock, scenting lavender air,
Came creaking through the cedar wood,
And huffled moth-wise in its lair!

One, two! One, two! Unlatch of cedar,
The lid, it yawed with cedar song!
He folded quilts, he folded beaver,
And tucked his childhood, cedar-long.

“Thou hast thou tamed the Cedrwock?” cried the heir,
“Come hither, camphorted, unscattered!”
They laughed amid the scented air—
’Twas cedar, cedar, every whiff thereafter.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about harvest moon in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Lunacy of the Amberfraught Harvestoon

’Twas moonthrise on the amberfraught,
And stilly-stalks did quiver;
All gourdly things in patchwork caught,
While zithersnaps did shiver.
Beware the Harvestoon, my buds!
The squash that gapes, the maize that sings!
Beware the Threshlemaw, and shun
The scritchful Cornwraith’s wings!

He took his sickleblade in hand,
Long time the pumkpin foe he sought—
Then rested by the tumbled land
Where starbeans thickly wrought.
And as in wheaten thought he stood,
The Harvestoon with eyes of flame
Came threshing through the stooked-up wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! Through straw and through!
The sickleblade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went a-gallumphing back.
“And hast thou slain the Harvestoon?
Come to my arms, my beaming boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas moonthset on the amberfraught,
And stilly-stalks lay stiller;
But still the moon-milk glow was caught
In every cider-driller.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about setts in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Settwockslither

’Twas troughy in the pibble-soil,  
And the moot-dark delvers crept;  
All fribbly were the gyre-roots,  
When the sett-scruffs never slept.  

Beware the Settwock, my stone-lad,  
With granite jowls that crunch!  
The reverberum snout it haves,  
That’ll scuncheon roads to mulch!  

He has a sleevish, slabber-shank  
And with his flaggy tail  
He thumps the lanes till cobbles dance  
Like crockery in a gale.  

Take now the mollock mallet, true—  
(Your arms may whicker soon)—  
And boot the clinker clamps, my groom,  
By light of tarmac-moon.  

When night’s a sooty treacle patch  
And thorplings quit their rungs,  
The Settwock blurges from his trench  
Where rumbling gravel hums.  

One, two! one, two! the tamping goes,  
Our conster-drummer roars;  
The chips all flock like moonstruck birds  
Round bevelled granite doors.  

His bouldered grin went wak-a-snack!  
His levees groaned in pain—  
Oh frabberday! he looped away  
And plunged to slabber-drain.  

And hast thou sludged the Settwock sly?  
Come splinter home for tea;  
O frabjous fit of sett-locked grit—  
The boulevard’s fancy-free!  

’Twas troughy in the pibble-soil,  
And the moot-dark delvers slept;  
Now level lies the chequered earth  
Where not a wheevish stone has wept.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on blown sand in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blusterblown of Duneclaw Keep

’Twas sunblench’d noon on the scorchèd wabe,
When grittle-gusts did gyre and gimble;
All parched were the palms, the camels drabe,
And the blister’d dunes did tremble.

“Beware the Blusterblown, my son!
The jaws that grit, the claws that rasp!
Beware the Siroc-skip, and shun
The frumious Sand-wasp!”

He took his khamsin-sword in hand:
Long time the quartzsome foe he sought—
So rested he by the xerophyte stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Blusterblown, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the thorny wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! Through grit and glare
The khamsin-sword went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its hair
He trudgèd dunesome back.

“And hast thou slain the Blusterblown?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas sunblench’d noon on the scorchèd wabe,
When grittle-gusts did gyre and gimble;
All parched were the palms, the camels drabe,
And the blister’d dunes did tremble.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about rubber band in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Snappity-Boing of Bandersnap  
’Twas stretchalot, and the snappity-boing  
Did gyre and gimble in the hand;  
All stretchy were the rubberlings,  
And the Bandersnap unplanned.  

“Beware the Snapjaw, my son!  
The jaws that click, the loops that fling!  
Beware the Twang-bird, and shun  
The frumious Pop-a-thing!”  

He took his stretchy sword in hand—  
Long time the maxi-loop he sought—  
So rested he by the Tumble-tree,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And, as in stretchy thought he stood,  
The Snapjaw, with eyes of blinking glue,  
Came twanging through the stretchy wood,  
And boingled as it flew!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The stretchy blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went elastic back.  

“And hast thou slain the Snapjaw, lad?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas stretchalot, and the snappity-boing  
Did gyre and gimble in the hand;  
All stretchy were the rubberlings,  
And the Bandersnap unplanned.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about something forgotten in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brumal Flinderglast  

’Twas in the mumble-gloaming, when the harkless zidders wheeze,  
All frumbly on the twisket-stones beneath the tattertrees—  
A snirtle-whisk lay snoozing where the plimpy glimmers glay;  
A thing had slipped from memory, an ossled who-knows-what away.  

In dimbral dusk it skithered, that un-namèd, un-keeped knoop,  
Past crackle-stumps of yoretime where the grobble-mosses droop;  
Its edges wore to vapour, like the sigh-sigh sigh of snow,  
Yet clung one breath of once-it-was, refusing to let go.  

Beware the shrunge-mind mitherer, my son, who nibbles at the day—  
Its nibbins leave no notches where a not-a-not may lay!  
For when the guggle-candles lose the ghost-glow in their glass,  
What flickered once as certaintude is murgled, gone, alas.  

He took his thoughts like tinder-sticks, he sparked them on the gloam,  
He hunted for the somewhen in the nowhere he called home;  
Where cloven clocks go clacker-whirr and centuries collapse,  
He sought the un-recollected in the hollows of the lapse.  

Then roundly whirled the timbrel-bells, and sloom the shadows swayed,  
As mem’ry’s marmish lantern flickered, dimly undismayed;  
Yet every echo echo-less re-folded into night,  
And nothing that was anywhen returned to give its light.  

So home he crept, the quester small, beneath the snither-stars;  
Though nothing now was found and kept, he cuddled all the scars.  
Come hush, come hush, the twindled dusk; come croon the lallaby—  
For every thing un-memoried still twinkles, lost, on high.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on falling leaves in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Frumious Leafly-Slide

’Twas autumntide, the skitterbreeze
Did gyre and tumble through the trees;
All crimbersome the maplemurk
Blew rustle-whisk where twilight lurks.
O frabbered bough! O amber-crack!
The leaflets snicker as they sack
From high to low, a pirouette—
Then flop, kerplunk, in leaflets met.

Beware the Quibberleaf, my son!
The fronds that flap, the stems that stun!
Beware the Gribblesap, and shun
The gurgle-drifting Grindle-wun!
It licks its gold and scarlet lip
And flips each tip with snickery-drip;
It giggles as it skelters free
Across the lawn in revelry.

He took his rake of bracken-bone
In hand, so he would not alone
Endure the whiffling canopy—
“One scrootch,” he cried, “and come with me!
We’ll catch them in their zithery glide,
Those leaflets in their frabjous pride!”
He whackled through the rustle-race
And joined the leaflets’ airy chase.

One, two! One, two! The crimson hoard
Came swirling like a burnished sword;
He swished and swooshed, then paused mid-leap—
The Quibberleaf was buried deep
Beneath a heap of crackle-crust,
Its scarlet laughter turned to dust.
“And hast thou slain the Quibberleaf?
Come hug my neck and share my grief!”

’Twas autumntide, the skitterbreeze
Had ceased to rumble through the trees;
Heaped golden in the twilight’s dome,
The leaves at last had found a home.
They snuggle in their crispy bed,
While overhead the branches spread—
O leaflets fallen, come what may,
We’ll rake you up another day!
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awle-Knabble’s Bight

’Twas a keenish night in the toolish glade—
     the awl-craft chirped and whirled—
The tim-bough squeaked where the benders played
     and the shavlings snip-snurl hurled.

Beware the Awle-Knabble, my son!
     Its twist-bite pointeth keen!
It skewers the glib and the unbegun
     and snicks them squeamly-bean.

With mordish swivels and borish twist
     it tunnels the gleamy groth,
Till holish hollows in hearts exist—
     a spiraling whistfling oath.

He took his gimble-shank in grip,
     through burrow-blur he pressed,
To meet the frabjous puncture-rip
     in ferrule-ic quest.

One, two! Twist-Through! The bright bit rasps and sings!
     It clings and rings, it zings and clings, and pore-tiny echoes wing!
The knockish obit-hole stood black and bare:
     he drew the keen thing through—“A-ha!” he cried, with triumphant stare,
     “I’ve awled—so have you!”

Come croodle home, bright burrower!
     Oh, gimble-spike of fame!
The hole-world sings whatsonaloo!
     He chortled as it came.

’Twas a keenish night in the toolish glade—
     the awl-craft lay uncouth—
And tim-bough dreams where the holes were made
     glow gig-goggler truth.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about hiraeth in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Hiraethwocky

’Twas hiraeth, and the slithery shore
Did gyre and gimble in the foam;
All wistful were the borogroves,
And the lost raths outroam.

“Beware the Hiraeth, my son!
The ache that bites, the pang that clings!
Beware the Long-Ago bird, and shun
The frumious Yesteryear-wings!”

He took his heart-sword in his hand:
Long time the manxome grief he sought—
So rested he by the sighing tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Hiraeth, with eyes of mist,
Came whiffling through the memory-wood,
And burbled as it kissed.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The heart-sword went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went a-grieving back.

“And hast thou slain the Hiraeth?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas hiraeth, and the slithery shore
Still gyres and gimbles in the foam;
All wistful are the borogroves,
And the lost raths outroam.

prompt: Compose a poem on proofing basket in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Proofingbasket’s Roundelay

’Twas bannock-time, and the wicker-wove  
Did gyre and gimble in the doughy gloam;  
All flimsy were the gluten loaves,  
And the yeast-beasts out-frothome.  

“Beware the Proofingbasket, son!  
The loops that snare, the coils that catch!  
Beware the gluten-snug, and shun  
The frumious over-proof batch!”  

He took his floured wand in hand:  
Long time the sticky foe he sought—  
So rested he by the kitchen stand,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in floured thought he stood,  
The Proofingbasket, round and deep,  
Came spiraling through the rising wood,  
And burbled as it seeped!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The floured wand went snicker-snack!  
He left it cool, he scored it true,  
And went galumphing back.  

“And hast thou slain the Proofingbasket?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas bannock-time, and the wicker-wove  
Did gyre and gimble in the doughy gloam;  
All flimsy were the gluten loaves,  
And the yeast-beasts out-frothome.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about key ring in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Jingletock Keys of Rindle-ring  
’Twas clinkish time in Cubilcraze: the keeperble locks all quave;  
All snickly with the clatterclicks, the jabberkeys engrave.  
“Beware the Ringwock, boldling clans! Those jaws that jam, that jaw open-erg!  
Beware the Fangfolds, shun the lack-clawed Bilpent twirlig!  

With metal-bright he clutched the might of brass-and-steelish chain;  
Then clickaswooped through underhoops where ringthings rise like rain.  
So swirled he in the night-maze coil, clikclacket song of clang;  
At break o’clock the Ringwock came, its teeth of tungsten tang!  

One-two-click! click-clackety! His keyblade turned—youf!  
It gnashed the jaws, untwisted laws, unlatched the danse-rack proof.  
He left it dead with belch-clank head, went jerking back t’ward docks,  
And jam-jumped to the keeper-bench, the jingling loppity-lux.  

“Hast slain the Ringwock, clankish boy? Come grasp my ossic slick!”  
He keying-blessed the lockly lad— “O frubious Ringclasp prick!”  
’Twas clinkish time in Cubilcraze: the keeperble locks applaud—  
The ring-gone foe now silent bowed beneath the odd-of-god.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about polynomial time versus nondeterministic polynomial time in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Polynomial-Jabberwock  
’Twas ver-NP-time, the slithy code  
did gyre and gamble on the RAM;  
all async’d were the queries’ load,  
and the servers bubbled with jam.  

“Beware the Polynomial-Jab, my son!  
The jaws that clip, the fangs that swap!  
Beware the Concert-Rank, and shun  
the furbish Combinatorial—pop!”  

He took his gill-y thread in hand;  
long time the stout sudoku foe he sought—  
so rested he ‘gainst a TM-band  
and stood a while in naught.  

And as in uffish bits he stood,  
the Polynomial-Jab with eyes aflame,  
came whiffling through the solvitude  
and burbled, “Answer’s the same!”  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
the quantum edge went blipper-blam!  
He left it dead; and on the head  
he scribbled chalky ⊕ or ⊖.  

“And hast thou slain the Polynomial-Jab?  
Come to my arms, my beamish class!  
O True-False day! A cert-decay!”  
He chortled in beta-pass.  

’Twas ver-NP-time, the slithy code  
did gyre and gamble on the RAM;  
all async’d were the queries’ load,  
and the servers—bubbled with jam.

info.topic: polynomial time versus nondeterministic polynomial time

label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on birthday candle in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Snickerflame’s Awake  
’Twas candlelight, and blitherskrimps  
    Did glow and gizzle round the cake;  
All wisping were the silver scrimps,  
    And melted wax did quake.  

“Beware the Snickerflame, my John,  
    Its sputterspit, its tangledwick!  
Beware the Glomperoof hot con,  
    The Sizzlescratch and Blick!”  

He took his gustygulp in hand,  
    Long time the wattled gleam he sought—  
So rested he by the sugar tree,  
    And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in toffeethought he stood,  
    The Snickerflame with puff of scorch  
Came whiffling through the icingwood,  
    And spindled wax upon its torch!  

One, two! One, two! The wish-whirl blew,  
    The gustygulp went whack-a-muff!  
He left it wheezing out the blue—  
    He wished it, puffed it—snuff.  

“And hast thou fluster-quelled the spark?  
    Come lift my cake-skipped squalls!”  
“Oh fractuskip! I doused the dark,  
    The Snickerflame it—falls!”  

’Twas candlelight, and blitherskrimps  
    Did glow and gizzle round the cake;  
All wisping were the silver scrimps,  
    And melted wax did quake.

prompt: Create a poem about deadhead run in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Deadhead Rumble-Thrum

’Twas diesel-dark and the slipstream sly;
Route sheets fluttered on the dashboard-sill;
All empty were the seats, and the sky
Hung hollow as a moon-moth’s frill.
“Beware the Deadhead Run, my son!
The fumes that choke, the gears that grind!
Beware the Haul-Road hum, and shun
The Caffeine-Adder mind!”

He took his thermos-orb in hand;
Long time the empty miles he sought—
So rested he by the weigh-station stand,
And stood awhile in thought.
And as in diesel thought he stood,
The Deadhead Run, with headlights flame,
Came thunder-bumbling through the wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The turbo-vorpal engine roared!
He left it dead, yet onward sped
With empty load still stored.
“And hast thou slain the Deadhead Run?
Yet still the route rolls on, my boy!
O frabjous day, but full dismay—
Another leg, ahoy!”

’Twas diesel-dark and the slipstream sly;
Route sheets fluttered on the dashboard-sill;
All empty were the seats, and the sky
Hung hollow as a moon-moth’s frill.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about spectral clustering in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Spectralclustletric Chortle-Gap

’Twas eigen-time in Graphomere, and eerie spectra gleamed,  
All k-way through the Node-a-bloom, the sibilant nodes dreamed;  
Proximity swam nak’dly blunt through Laplace-smoothed expanse,  
And the cutting k-nife whispered “Slice!—let clusters twixt us dance!”  
“Beware the Spurious-Link, my coder!  
The edges that mislead!  
Beware the Variance-clout, and shun  
The Phantom-centroids’ creed!”  

He took his Gram-vector spear in hand; long time the max-sig sought—  
So rested he by the SVD, and Eigen-insight wrought.  
Then, spectral-projection thrumming, came the Sampling-Wyrmish-lot,  
With tentacles of noise and knell came graph-soot murk and spot!  
One, two! One, two! Through manifold-spin!  
The spectrum-knife went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
Returned cluster-wise back.  

“And hást thou slain the Spurious-Link?  
Come to my arms, my beamish dweeb!  
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!”  
He chortled in log-space-eig.  

’Twas eigen-time in Graphomere, and eerie spectra gleamed,  
All k-way through the Node-a-bloom, the sibilant nodes dreamed;  
Proximity swam nak’dly blunt through Laplace-smoothed expanse,  
And the cutting k-nife whispered “Slice!—let clusters twixt us dance!”
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on sprezzatura in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Canting of the Spressled Bard

’Beware the Spressled Bard, my son!
The wrists that snap, the cuffs that fling!
Beware the studied nonchalance,
the careless-seeming everything!’

He took his vorpal scarf in hand:
long days he stalked the strolling-green—
then rested by the fountain grand,
and stood awhile bemused, unseen.

And as in offish thought he stood,
the Spressled Bard, with eyes of flame,
came strutting through the eucalypt wood,
and hummed as if un-tuned to name.

One, two! One, two! And through and through—
the casual blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dangling, half askew,
and sauntered on, not glancing back.

’Has thou slain the Spressled Bard?
Re-tie thy tie, glad boy, and cheer!
O frabjous day, callooh! callay!’
He chortled with no trace of fear.

’Twas brillig; breezes billowed light;
so easy slipped the studied art—
the effortless was all in sight:
the grace of seeming lack of heart.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about falling leaves in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brisklefall of Autumning

’Twas amberdusk, and gustly trees  
Did creak and clatter through the breeze;  
All crimsy were the leaflets’ flight,  
And twirlygigs took sudden height.  

“Beware the Brisklefall, my child,  
That drops from yonder boughs so wild!  
Beware the Saffrondrake, and shun  
The frumious Windle-shun!”  

He took his rakish rake in paw,  
And sought the crackling leaf-torn maw;  
Long he hunted through the rustling gloam,  
Till leaves like burning ember-roam.  

And as in amber thought he stood,  
The Brisklefall, with rustling hood  
Came swirling through the maple maze,  
And burbled thanks in smoky praise!  

One, two! One, two! The rake it swept,  
Through skirling heaps where shadows crept.  
He left it dead, and with its gold  
He trudged a path through evening cold.  

“And hast thou slain the Brisklefall?  
Come rest your brow, my leavesome thrall!”  
O fractious day! Cascading cheer!  
He chortled in his rustle-gear.  

’Twas amberdusk, and gustly trees  
Did creak and clatter through the breeze;  
All crimsy were the leaflets’ flight,  
And twirlygigs took sudden height.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about Gödel's incompleteness theorem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gödelwocky

’Twas theorem-time in Logiland, and the symbols all were straying,
Did gyre and gimble in the proof, while axioms lay playing.
“Beware the Gödelwock, my son!  The jaws that bite, the clause that snares!
Beware the Consist-bird, and shun the frumious Completeness-bears!”

He took his formal sword in hand; long time the max-i-ome he sought—
So rested he by the syntax tree, and stood awhile in thought.
And as in uffish doubt he stood, the Gödelwock, with eyes of flame,
Came wiffling through the metal-log, and burbled as it came!

One, two!  One, two!  And through and through the diagonal slash went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head he built a self-referent plaque.
“And hast thou slain the Gödelwock?  Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day!  Callooh!  Callay!”  He chortled in his joy.

’Twas theorem-time in Logiland, and the symbols all were straying,
Did gyre and gimble in the proof—yet Truth itself lay braying:
“For every system sound and nice, a statement stands outside:
‘This claim is not provable,’ it grins—and cannot be denied.”
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on key ring in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Clangor of the Keyringwock

’Twas clang and clatter in the hall,  
The pocket jangle, pocket-fall,  
All mimsy were the metal rings,  
That gyred and gimbled by their strings.  

“Beware the Keyringwock, my son!  
The jaws that snatch, the claws that stun!  
Beware the jagged jingle-jack,  
And shun the frumious keyring-pack!”  

He took his swiveling swissblade brand,  
Long time the brassy foes he scanned—  
So rested he by the doorway tree,  
And stood awhile in reverie.  

And, as in oofy thought he stood,  
The Keyringwock, with clinking hood,  
Came jangling through the tulgey air,  
And jargled, snatching keys with flair!  

One, two! One, two! The blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its tag,  
Went galumphing back.  

“And hast thou slain the Keyringwock?  
Come to my arms, my beamish lock!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his jingling joy.  

’Twas clang and clatter in the hall,  
The pocket jangle, pocket-fall,  
All mimsy were the metal rings,  
That gyred and gimbled by their strings.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about hollow grind in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Hollowgrobil’s Hone  
’Twas hollowgrobil, edge and spine,  
That snicker-snacked along the blade,  
With grind so thin it sang supine—  
A whispery worm where sparks were made.  

Beware the burr-blink, son of steel,  
It curls like smoke in moonlit mist;  
The bevel-bite, though cold and real,  
Will vanish with a hollow twist!  

The whetting wheel went whirrly-whirrr,  
As gritstone ground the groove half-gone;  
With slurpy-slurp the strop would purr,  
Till shadows fled from every lawn.  

One, two! and through the grit and glaze  
The hollowed hollow took its flight;  
Its crescents gleamed in lunar haze,  
Like silver seraphs cloaked in night.  

So take this hollow, keen yet slight,  
And guard it from the rusting rooks;  
Its ghostly grin cuts clean and bright—  
A whispered worm in all our books.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about shortest path in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shortwocky’s Path

’Twas Dijkstra, and the slithy edge  
Did curl and twist through graphy glade:  
All mimsy were the weighted hedge,  
As shortest paths the nodes arrayed.  

Beware the Shortwock, child, and shun  
The frumious loops that bite, that snare!  
Take up thy Vorpal Vector-gun,  
And seek the least of edges there.  

He took his labels crisp and bright,  
Long time he sought the greedy node;  
So rested he by the tree of light  
And stood a while in min-code.  

And as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Shortwock came, with paths ablaze,  
Came whiffling through the vertex-wood,  
With edges snorting, greedy ways!  

One two! One two! The labels flew—  
Through slithy loops the update passed—  
He left it dead, its cost he knew,  
With parent links he backtracked fast.  

‘And hast thou solved the Shortwock’s quest?  
O frabjous day! Calloh! Callay!’  
He chortled in the graph compressed;  
The shortest path was found! Hurray!  

’Twas Dijkstra, and the slithy edge  
Did curl and twist through graphy glade:  
All mimsy were the weighted hedge,  
As shortest paths the nodes arrayed.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on blown sand in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Whisprush of the Duneblown Day

’Twas suncrack noon, and the gritgrove sighed,  
All shiver-skinned in the heat-haze wide;  
The sandspry snorkeled through scorch and shade,  
And the dune-drakes danced where the mirage played.  

“Beware the Blustersnatch, my son!  
The jaws that grit, the claws that stun!  
Beware the Whirlwhip bird, and shun  
The frumious Dustiflung!”  

He took his vorpal shovel bright,  
He twirled it thrice in the glaring light;  
Then rested long by the salt-crust tree,  
And stood a-wait in the blowy lee.  

One, two! One, two! Through sizzle and glare  
The Blustersnatch came whiffling air;  
It burbled, churning the quartz and shell,  
And flung whole hills in a harrumphing swell!  

One, two! One, two! The shovel swung—  
A slice, a swipe, a stinging tongue!  
He left it blind in a glassy dune,  
And danced away to the blistered moon.  

“And hast thou slain the Blustersnatch?  
Come to my arms, my beamish batch!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his sandy sleigh.  

’Twas suncrack noon, and the gritgrove sighed,  
All shimmer-skinned in the heat-haze wide;  
The sandspry snorkeled through scorch and shade,  
And the dune-drakes danced where the mirage played.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awlwhack of Toolerwock

’Twas brillig, and the slim-screws gripe
   Did gimble in the vise-all clamp;
All mimsy were the birchwood stripes,
   And the raw hide did cramp.

“Beware the Awlwhack, my keen-eyed son!
   The point that pokes, the shaft that snags!
Beware the Punchbird’s prick, and shun
   The frumious Leather-rags!”

He took his burnish’d awl in hand—
   Long time the corksome hide he sought—
Then rested by the stitchen tree,
   And stood awhile in thought.

And as in awf’l thought he stood,
   The Awlwhack, eyes of needle-bright,
Came whiffling through the tangle-wood,
   And burbled holes in hide outright!

One, two! One, two! Through belt and boot!
   The burnish’d blade went snicker-snack!
He left it stuck, its job well took,
   And went a-galloping back.

“And hast thou slain the Awlwhack true?
   Come share my leather, beamish boy!
O frabjous stitch! Callooh! Callay!”
   He chortled in his joy.

’Twas brillig, and the slim-screws gripe
   Did gimble in the vise-all clamp;
All mimsy were the birchwood stripes,
   And the raw hide did cramp.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about something forgotten in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Snitherblat of Yesteryore

’Twas brillig, and the slithy toves  
Did gyre and gimble in the gloam;  
All mimsy were the hushy droves  
That once had caroled home.  

Beware the Snitherblat, my child!  
The fume that fizzles, eye that snores!  
Beware the hush-hush, running wild,  
And shun the clapping doors!  

He took his vorpal slate in hand—  
Long time the woxum foe he sought—  
Then rested he by the tumtum tree,  
And mused a musy thought.  

And as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Snitherblat, with breath of rust,  
Came whiffling through the dusky wood,  
Its memory turned to dust.  

One, two! One, two! The slate went crack—  
He left it dead, and with its name  
He went galumphing, ne’er came back,  
For none recall the same.  

“And hast thou slain the Snitherblat?  
Come to my arms, my beamish lad!  
O frabjous day!”—but none could say  
What thing it was they had.  

’Twas brillig, and the slithy toves  
Did gyre and gimble in the gloam;  
All mimsy were the hushy droves—  
The Snitherblat… unknown.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on spectral clustering in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Spectralclustergalumph!

’Twas on the graph so sparsely,
The vertices did gyre and gimble,
All flimsy were the edgèd ties,
That k-means could not nimble.

“Beware the Laplacian, my son!
The eigenvalues that bite, the eigenvectors catch!
Beware the Gaussian kernel, and shun
The frumious spectral snatch!”

He took his matrix wand in hand,
Long time the eigendecom he sought,
Then rested he by the k-th tree,
And eigen-angled a thought.

And as in affin’ish thought he stood,
The Laplacian with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey graph,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! Through subspace dim!
The matrix went vorpal-slice!
He left it dead, with eigenhead—
Went galumphing back to k-clusters nice.

“And hast thou slain the Laplacian?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas on the graph so sparsely,
The vertices did gyre and gimble,
All flimsy were the edgèd ties—
Yet spectralclustergalumph did nimble!
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about cedar chest in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Cedarwock Chest

’Twas midnight in the attic nook  
and warpwood beams did groan and quake;  
all moth-soft were the quilted shooks  
that hunkered in the chest-dark wake.  

Beware the Cedarknarl, my girl,  
the saw-scent jaw that clamp-lock clicks;  
beware the Camphorqueen in swirl’—silk  
who moth-hawk hunts the yarn-tied nix.  

She took her lavender locket spear  
and cedar-scented candle crown;  
long time the cloistral dark she’d peer’d,  
so silent ’mong the moon-flung down.  

And as in woollen wrap she stood,  
the Cedarknarl with hinges wide  
did groan its cinnamon-bark hood—  
it huffed a resin-fug inside!  

One, two! One, two! and through!—she thrust  
the locket deep in camphor’s fold;  
she left it dead, and with its dust  
the cedar-scent rolled rich and bold.  

And hast thou ta’en the Cedarknarl?  
Come to my arms, my beaming bride;  
O resin-day! Wood-scent huzzah—  
she hauled the quilts safely outside!  

’Twas midnight in the attic nook—  
sweet cedar kept the dreams in tune;  
still warpwood beams did chuckle-croon  
’neath lavender-silver moon.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about proofing basket in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Proofing-Basketry of Brot
’Twas proofing-time, and the wicker-twigs  
Did coil and crimp in the ferment-rack;  
All floured were the grooves, and the gluten-pigs  
Did snuffle in coils of doughy back.  
“Beware the Proofing-Basket, boy!  
The seams that nip, the coils that clasp!  
Beware the sour-clouds, and shun  
The floury-flapping gasp!”  

He took his beery blade in hand—  
Long time the dough-blob foe he sought—  
So rested he by the oven-stand  
And stood awhile in thought.  
And as in rising thought he stood,  
The Proofing-Basket, coil and seam,  
Came spiralling through the bready wood  
And burbled as it dream.  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The beery blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He turned the dough right back.  
“And hast thou tamed the Baskety beast?  
Come to my arms, my glutenous son!  
O frabjous loaf! Choublatious roast!”  
He chortled in his pun.  

’Twas proofing-time, and the wicker-twigs  
Did curl and crown in the golden crack;  
All crusty rose the loafy pigs—  
Come slice, my love, come smack!
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on hiraeth in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Slumbrous-Hiraeth
’Twas twilf and the heatherlongs
Did gimble and gyre in the brume:
All wistful were the aether-ways,
And the brythtle homes exhumed.

“Beware the Hiraeth, lostling-child!
The ache that bites, the sigh that clings!
Beware the drindle-draal, and shun
The fruminous nearing-things!”

He took his yestermate in hand:
Long time the saudade-seek he sought—
He rested by the mem’ree-urn,
And hiraethed while he thought.

And as in hushful thought he stood,
The Hiraeth, swol’n with sigh and shade,
Came fleeting through the fernfold pale,
And murmured what once was made.

One, two! One, two! Through grief and glim!
The yestermate went snicker-snatch!
It sliced the longing-shadows dim,
Then swum it home to thatch.

“Hast thou dispatched the Hiraeth, dear?
Delight, O child! My heartbeat-stream!”
He whimhers in its wistful arms,
And home is never the same.

’Twas twilf and the heatherlongs
Still gimble and gyre in the brume:
All wistful are the aether-ways—
Fore-dawns we can’t resume.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about deadhead run in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Dread-Head Rune**  

’Twas gloam along the turn-pike, and the tocsin tracks did quiver,  
All rust-red rails a-shuddering where the midnight coaches slither;  
Solemn stood the signal towers, cinder-crowned, malign,  
And the blackened sleepers muttered of a ghostly engine’s whine.  

“Beware the Deadhead Rune, my son, the deadest run of nine-oh-three,  
The clacking claw, the wheezing draw, the hollow-gated plea!  
For drivers pale as porter-dregs will whistle down the gloom—  
Then haul a train of coffin-crates no living soul dare loom.”  

He took his lantern trembling, and his father’s iron pass,  
Through soot-smoked fog to Fumble-Plath, to wait the dooméd mass;  
His boots beat time with terror-thrum as shadow-boilers howled,  
And grim the ghast headlamp grew, a cyclope eye un-cowled.  

A hulk of clanging tomb-petals, all shivered plate and rivet,  
Clanked forth upon the nowhere line—no fireman, no ticket;  
Its nameboard bore charred lettering that bled a phosphor sting:  
DEADHEAD NO RETURN it read, to nowhere, off the wing.  

A shriek of sliding pistons!—like a banshee’s iron kiss—  
While carriage shells of blackened lace exhaled a sepulchral hiss.  
On every blind the spectered shades of riders past pressed grim—  
Their faces steamed like post-fog glass, their whispers never dim.  

O horrid headless porters! O ghastly ticket clerks!  
They beckoned him with tattered gloves of moon-bleaching murks.  
Yet brave he strode the footplate step, his heart a coal of cold,  
Where drivers, faceless, offered him a seat of spectral mold.  

One, two! One, two! The throttle snapped—through iron jaws they swept,  
Past mileboard skulls and signal poles where ragged lantern-wept;  
They clanged through cryptic cuttings, by cenotaph and crag,  
Till clocks unraveled, maps burned blank, and night-bells tolling sagged.  

He gripped the ghost-fire shovel, fed the furnace griefs unknown,  
While ashes fell like memories that never had been sown.  
Then sudden—hollow whistle shrill—the whole train ghostly thinned,  
And only clacking echoes and the wind of what had been.  

Back through the vapor-mantled gate he crept at break of gloam,  
With furnace soot upon his brow, forever bound to roam;  
His lantern flame burns bluish still, his ticket—torn, transfused—  
For once you ride the dreadhead run, you’re neither quite alive nor used.  

“And hast thou slain the Deadhead Rune? Come, tell me, darling boy!”  
He answers not, but whistles low the broken-metal alloy.  
So hush, my sprout, when twilight clacks and the night rails start to moan—  
The Deadhead always hungers; it’s your own train now, your own.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about setts in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Black-Rood Borrowlow Settsong

’Twas hushling on the hollom rise  
And the mire-wumps did prowl;  
All grobble-stay the moss-wet skies  
Dispersed the burrowing owl.  

O burly-bill the badger bold!  
With snuffersnout he trod;  
His coat a dusk of nugget gold,  
His claws the iron rod.  

“Take heed, my kit, the rum-ridge net  
That snares the nightly dell;  
Take heed the poacher’s glimmer-pet,  
That twinkles, mawks, and fell.  
Caress the moon-rot sett-of-stone,  
Its gateway dark and deep;  
There snuggers down the clod-oak throne  
Where even whispers sleep.”  

He took his slate-scrawled stave in paw,  
And scramblit through the glade;  
To burrow-gate, without a flaw,  
The windingworld he swayed.  

Then while he doozled in the ground,  
With huffle breath stirred wide,  
Came snatch-men groping, lantern-bound,  
Their hounds on spindled stride.  

One—twang!—the barbnet swole and spread,  
Its iron vines outran;  
But snuffersnout, by moonlight led,  
Kerflooft—he karked the man!  

Through itchblade weed and shamrockrile,  
He spledged their glimmer down;  
Into the mire-wet bruise-land, vile,  
A lantern sank to drown.  

“So quick, my kit, through chankling peat,  
Where moon-moss tickles nose;  
The sett is snug, the dark is sweet,  
And no black fearment grows.”  

’Twas hushling still on hollom rise,  
The mire-wumps kept at bay;  
Badgers a-bulge with soot-dust eyes  
Dreamed borrow-brite till day.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on rubber band in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Elasticord's Last Snap

’Twas twizzling at the break of snap,
     When zungus coils went twistle-toy,
So stretchified the wobble-trap—
     The elasticord, in boingy joy!

Beware the Pingful Gripperclaw,
     Its loops that pry, its pulse that stings!
Shun the grapple-grip, the squeezing flaw
     That Yankles snaps and splits the springs!

She took her springled shaft in hand,
     Long time the snorful foe she sought—
Then leapt in midst of rubberland,
     While slack-times shrivelled, knotted, taut.

One, two! One, two! Through thwip and throng,
     The stretch-swung blade sang spungle-song!
She looped it ’round the gripper’s jaw,
     Came snickering home in triumph long.

“And hast thou snapped the Gripperclaw?
     Come clasp my coils, O boingy Day!”
O frabjous loop! She caroled in awe,
     Her rubber realm entwined in play.

’Twas twizzling at the close of snap,
     When zungus coils went twistle-toy,
So stretchified the wobble-trap—
     The elasticord, in boingy joy!

prompt: Create a poem about birthday candle in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Snickerflame of Candlewink

Twas brisklydark, the yestermorn,  
When zithertongued the zabblehorn;  
All gimbering round the butterblades  
The wicklets quibbled, candle-born.  

Beware the Snickerflame, my boy!  
The flickersnatch, the wax that wails!  
Beware the sparkledrip, and shun  
The frumious puffit-gales.  

He took his vorpal match in hand,  
Long time the waxy foe he sought—  
So rested he by the sugared tree  
And doodled dreams of cake-unsought.  

And as in glimmerthought he dazed,  
The Snickerflame, with eyes of ember,  
Came waxenwhiffling through the glaze,  
And snuffed the shadows, dim-remember!  

One-twinkle-two! And through-and-through!  
The vorpal-match went flamering!  
It left the wick in glowing blue,  
A wishing-whirl still smoldering.  

“Hast slain the flame, my birthday blade?  
Come hug my arms and candle-cheer!  
Huzzah! The wax shall drip and fade—  
But wish not gone, it lingers here.”  

Twas brisklybright, the here-now-day,  
When zithertongued the zabblehorn;  
All gimbring on the butterblades  
The Snickerflame—no more forlorn.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about polynomial time versus nondeterministic polynomial time in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tractable Tractock  
(From an Apprentice Algorist’s Algorithmic Almanack)

’Twas P-time, and the nimble bits  
Did gyre and gimble in the RAM;  
All wobbly were the data-sets,  
While NP-phantoms sang “I AM.”  

Beware the Tractock, my sweet prover,  
That mouth whose yes and no collide;  
Its proof-wings brush each mortal cover,  
Then skritch-scratch scrawl on every side!  

He took his rigor-prone sharp quill;  
Long time he sought the witness-path;—  
Yet every path re-closed in nil,  
Befogged by some infernal math.  

As doubtfog o’clock, the Tractock sprack,  
Its checkleaf whiffling in quick time,  
And while the poly-circles stack  
It snapped each hint like runic rhyme.  

One-two! One-two! Through lattice-lair  
The red-ink lemma went slish-slice,  
Its truth-curve kinked the toxic air;  
Still P=NP? Just not precise.  

Has slain he then the Tractock grand?  
Has caught the key, unlocked the jam?  
Come claim me prize, all cipher-land!—  
Yet echoes only sing “I AM.”  

’Tis P-time still, and nimble bits  
Still gyre and gimble in the RAM;  
All wobbly are our data-sets,  
While future solvers sing “I AM.”

info.topic: polynomial time versus nondeterministic polynomial time

label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on harvest moon in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Harvestoon

’Twas autumntide, and the amberdusk
Did gyre and gimble round the sheaf;
All flinty were the stalks of husk,
And the scarecrow’s teeth were leef.

“Beware the Harvestoon, my son!
The orb that blushes, gold and wide!
Beware the gourdlechuck, and shun
The frumious pumpkin-tide!”

He took his sickle-sword in hand:
Long time the manxome moon he sought—
So rested he by the wheaten stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Harvestoon, with glow of grain,
Came whiffling through the stubblewood,
And burbled in the lane!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The sickle-sword went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Harvestoon?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas autumntide, and the amberdusk
Did gyre and gimble round the sheaf;
All flinty were the stalks of husk,
And the scarecrow’s teeth were leef.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about sprezzatura in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Splendiferous Sprezzaturile

’Twas brillish, and the snoddy granes  
did shimmer nonchalant the quave;  
the svelticles in loosened chains  
went whist-sway-breezing brave.  

“Beware the Sprezzaturile, son—  
the sidleclomp, the languish-hair!  
Beware the non-thought-soon-is-done,  
and shun the seem-didn’t-care!”  

He took his vorpal easeblade drawn,  
his shrug-of-shard hung slack;  
upon a lilt he sauntered on,  
a carelessy attack.  

One, deux! and thrimble-fy!  O quaint  
the lolligance he spun!  
He left them gasping—How? Can’t!—  
yet looked as if ’twas fun.  

“And hast thou slain the Sprezzaturile?  
Come clasp my laissez-dar!  
O laudable, cool-wild, free-brill be!  
We accolade—no flair!”  

’Twas brillish, and the snoddy granes  
did shimmer nonchalant the quave;  
the svelticles in loosened chains  
went whist-sway-breezing brave.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about suitcase in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Suitcase of the Snithering Snatch

’Twas packering, and the zippered snout
Did gribble-grope along the floor;
All flimsy were the straps about,
And the buckles clacked for more.

“Beware the Suitcase, traveller’s bane!
The snaps that snatch, the wheels that roll!
Beware the pop-up handle—vain—
And shun the lock-hole’s hole!”

He took his vorpal garment-bag
In hand; long time the iron case
He sought—then rested by the tag
And stood awhile in place.

And, as in uffish thought he leant,
The Suitcase, with a sudden wheeze,
Came clatter-bumping, bent and bent,
And burbled through the breeze.

One, two! One, two! The clasps went clack—
The vorpal bag went snicker-snack—
He left it dead, and with its tag
He trundled home the pack.

“And hast thou slain the Suitcase dread?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas packering, and the zippered snout
Did gribble-grope along the floor;
All flimsy were the straps about,
And the buckles clacked for more.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on spectral clustering in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Graphwocky

’Twas brillig in the datapool,  
when graph-nodes gyred and gimbaled cool;  
all mimsy were the edges’ weight,  
for pairwise paths to oscillate.

“Beware the Laplacian, my son!  
the jaws that snip, the cuts that stun.  
Beware the Eigenbird that sings  
its spectral tune—of hidden rings.”  

Into the manifold he stepped;  
the eigenvalues softly leapt.  
First eigen one, then two, three, four—  
until the k-space op’d its door.

He took his matrix-blade in grip,  
its entries zero, off-di-snip;  
the k-means sword he swung so bright,  
a k-means dance of clustering light.  

The Laplacian came whiffling near,  
its second-smallest eigen clear;  
it burbled out an eigenvec,  
its coords like starlight in a speck.  

One, two! One, two! The clusters flew!  
each node unto its chosen hue;  
he left it blinking, labeled right,  
a spectral vict’ry in the night.  

“Hast slain the Graphwocky?” they cried.  
He stood amid the colors wide:  
“O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”—  
for nodes now grouped in grand array.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about deadhead run in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Slumberton Snarlbust Gripe
’Twas down the glumrail swaptrack’s crawl—
all timber-rattled bones and steam—
The clatterclacks went warglewargle,
and coffin-freight ran off to dream.

Beware the Deadhead Run, my lad,
that whifflewobble ghostbound spree;
its wheels are glass, its whistles mad,
all cindered in nopay decree.

With suitcase full of tumbleweed
and hat distilled from yesteryear,
He clomb aboard that shadow-reed
of coaches void of fare or tear.

The brakegrips sighed like widowed wrens;
the signal smirked a jaundiced green.
Past towns of smithereened mens’ dens
it rolled, pre-haunting the unseen.

O frabjous dark! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in caboose profound;
Though empty miles merged into gray,
Deadheading made no earthly sound.

Come hush, return; the timetable’s past,
no ticket will be clipped or burned.
The rails will greet him last to last—
a mome-unmet, unclocked, un-earned.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about sprezzatura in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sprazzle-Wocky

’Twas brillig, and the sprightly gown   
      Did gyre and gimbel on the sly;   
All mimsy was the cuff undone,   
      And the pocket-square flew by.   

“Beware the Sprezzle-Wock, my son!   
      The cuffs that flap, the tie askew!   
Beware the studied nonchalance,   
      And shun the look too true!”   

He took his watch-chain in his hand:   
      Long time the rakish foe he sought—   
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,   
      And stood awhile in thought.   

But, as in non-lithe stance he stood,   
      The Sprezzle-Wock, with sleeve aglow,   
Came wiffling down the cobbled brood,   
      And burbled careless so!   

One, two! One, two! And through and through   
      The silk-lined sleeve went snicker-snack!   
He left it dead, with button three—   
      Yet looked it never back.   

“Has thou slain the Sprezzle-Wock?   
      Come to my arms, my beau-ish boy!   
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”   
      He chortled in his joy.   

’Twas brillig, and the sprightly gown   
      Did gyre and gimbel on the sly;   
All mimsy was the cuff undone,   
      And the pocket-square flew by.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on falling leaves in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fallowcroak Timberfall  
’Twas leaf-fall tide, and barrow streams  
Did blur and burble through the night;  
All flimsy were the sallow beams,  
And the poplar bones hissed white.  

Beware the Bracklewift, my son,  
That flurrs the brindle shade—  
Beware the Driftingrake, that spun  
The moon-bleached golden braid.  

He took his limb-lance in his hand,  
Long time the sedge-gloom sought—  
So rested he beneath the stand  
Of whistlenut, and thought.  

And as in amberflank he stood,  
The Bracklewift, with plume of rust,  
Came flurbell-flutter-flamming through  
The tempeach flake and dust.  

One-two! One-two! Through clatterbrown  
The limb-lance flickered keen!  
He left it dead, and with its crown  
He caught the russet sheen.  

“Hast slain the Bracklewift, my child?  
Come palmerbride, partake!  
O frabjous day! Calloo, callay!”  
He flang into the rake.  

’Twas leaf-fall tide, and barrow streams  
Did burble soft in shade;  
All flimsy turned to silvered dreams—  
And the goldgroves softly swayed.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awlwhack’s Awlful Ballad

’Twas brillig, and the slimy awl  
Did gyre and gimble through the board;  
All flimsy were the fibres’ scrawl,  
And the grainy gash out-poured.  

“Beware the Awlwhack, my good lad!  
The jaws that prick, the points that catch!  
Beware the brad and shun the pad  
That holds the timber’s snatch!”  

He took his stoutish awl in grip:  
Long time the manxsome hole he sought—  
So rested he by the splintered chip,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Awlwhack, eye of burnished steel,  
Came whiffling through the ebon wood,  
And burbled holes with zeal!  

One, two! One, two! Through oak and yew  
The stabbish blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its thread  
He stitched the splinters back.  

“And hast thou slain the Awlwhack’s dread?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas brillig, and the slimy awl  
Did gyre and gimble through the board;  
All flimsy were the fibres’ scrawl,  
And the grainy gash out-poured.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about shortest path in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shortestpatheth Jabberwock
’Twas netwise and the slimy graphs  
Did gyre and gimble in the maze;  
All vertexy were the polygraffs,  
And the edgeways danced in haze.  

“Beware the Shortestpatheth, my son!  
The jaws that bite, the weights that snare!  
Beware the Dijkstrabird, and shun  
The frumious Bellman’s lair!”  

He took his metric sword in hand;  
Long time the minmax foe he sought—  
So rested he by the heap-tree grand,  
And queued awhile in thought.  

And as in greedy thought he stood,  
The Shortestpatheth, with costs of flame,  
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,  
And burbled as it came!  

One, two! One, two! Through arcs it flew,  
The metric blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.  

“And hast thou slain the Shortestpatheth?  
Come to my arms, my beamish lad!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas netwise and the slimy graphs  
Did gyre and gimble in the maze;  
All vertexy were the polygraffs,  
And the edgeways danced in haze.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on birthday candle in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Splendiferous Squishflame
’Twas brillig in the bakeabell, the frostlings fizzled bright,
The cupcakit cradled cautious its wax-lit dream of light;
All morslemims were mirthy-dimmed, the sugarbellies sighed—
For one small spit of candlewarb would soon be nullified.

Beware the Birthflame, birthday spark, the choco-wick that snerks!
It prattles in its tallow-tower, with icing whispers, smirks.
It counts each heart-wish silently, a wicket full of fate—
Then—pft!—it quenches, leaving naught but smoke-spun wisps of late.

He took his vimble wafflewand, he twirled the waffliest wish,
He summoned th’ edge of wonderment in every sugared dish;
Then flupp! went flashaflibber! he breathed the daring air—
But snuck amid the velvet dark, the candle sniffed despair.

“O flamelet, flickered frotherkin, abandon not thine gleam!
Thou bearest the oracley dreams that bob within the cream!”
Yet—whisp!—it swooned beneath a sigh, its crimson toppled low,
And sneezed a single sooty snow that drifted soft and slow.

As candylight went wobbling south, the cupcage grieved asleep,
The frosting wept icicle tears; the sprinkles ceased to peep.
Still hushed within the velvet nook where silent miracles crouch,
The wisher clutched the smoky ghost—its secret touch—Oouch!

So childlings, guard your candlehopes; grow cuppateers of cheer—
Sing louder to the dwindling spark, relight its flibbered sphere!
For though the Birthflame snuffs to hush, its whisper never scats—
It lingers in the lamplight of tomorrow’s birthday hats.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about rubber band in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Glimmergalloping Snappomancer

’Twas brynkling at the snap of tide,  
the snatchersnapple loop—when rov’rknots  
of quiverquant elastic crackled, coils  
curb’d in crepitating clops of bogglebounce.

Beware the Stretchlebeast, my lad,  
that twang-torqued tangle in thrawn nooks!  
It twixteth and twyxeth, sproinging wide,  
with mogglish lungy yawns of ploop!

Seek thou the plinky-wink of momblestamps—  
(rirkle-ruckled skin of polyurethane)  
and clutch the strop of shimmerstance  
to sling a snip-snap snorlathon.

He took the snookslings in his grip,  
palm-bright, ring-clever, burping slackened breath,  
then danced a doodled dervish-dip—  
espargle!—and muzzled the gasps of death.

One, two! One, two! Through celadon air  
the beastlet boinged, a spindled throbber,  
till ribald b’lastic twail ensnared  
its snarl in frillish gawing lobber.

By stretching sock and singing gum,  
he serpeteenth-knotted the loopwhirl doom—  
the cavity clenched, the snapper undone,  
a velvetened vesper—spillt to fume.

“Oh glibbering joy!” he yelloped, gleeful, grand,  
“Thou wily, cowardly stretchthing, be gone!”  
He frumphled home through thundertanned land,  
a victor crowned with taut-looped crown.

’Twas brynkling at the snap of tide,  
the snatchersnapple loop—when rov’rknots  
of quiverquant elastic crackled, coils  
curb’d in crepitating clops of bogglebounce.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about key ring in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ringkeyborogris' Parade
’Twas twilight in the clutch-noon, and the twirlybutton clocks
   Did gimble in the gibble-gab riveting the air;
All jingly were the linkshopps, and the temper-turning fobs
   Churn-whinged the pockets nowhere.

Beware the Ringkeyborogris, my son—the teeth that clack, the jaws that jangle—
   Beware the Lockjaw Clove and shun the frumious Splitting-prong!
If titling toward the claspibore, you’ll hear a metal tangle
   When screwlet midges shrill their song.

He took his trusty haspblade in hand—long time the chinky rogue he sought—
   Then rustered, rusting in the core of darkened-hall and hall;
He rested by the Splitterhatch, and stood a stricken thought,
   Where keyspells hung in shining fall.

And as in minikin musay he stood, the Ringkeyborogris came clinking
   Through the thimble-shadow fog; It burbled mirth in bronze!
One, two—one, two! The haspblade flew, all snicker-snapping, clink-re-linking,
   At last the jingleboss was ponzed!

Hasp thy blade, thy clink has triumphed! “O frabjous day!” he ringlet cried;
   “Callooh! Callay!” the metal rings parade.
But down the echo passkeyturn, a hundred half-prongs clicked—wide
   The Ringkeyborogris re-eyed with spade.

’Twas twilight in the clutch-noon, and the twirlybutton clocks
   Re-clanged again their marching chimes;
All jingly were the linkshopps, but the pockets gripped their flocks
   Around the ring where rhyme re-climbs.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on cedar chest in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cedar Cest of Ulberwick

`Twas brumley in the cheverly loft—
And bobbing timbre-tunnels rang—
The elder-sinewed cedar chest
Slooshed open with a clust’ry twang.
“Beware the Cherish-thing, my son,
With hopes reclused and thistle-keys,
Beware the Nanna-moth that flits
On ghost-lace burrowed by the breeze!”

He snibbed his scosp and stowed the plume
Of must-recondensed christ’ning gown,
Then sought the padded histle-room
Where cedared bulkheads gravelled down.
Death-mothlings nattered thorn-creed vows,
While gran-balm lingered, reamed and razed—
He clawed a latch that cawed like rooks
and through the gloom he stared—amazed!

In scents of spindled Passovers
Past graduations crimpt in frost,
The cedar chest unhaunted cackles,
Its memories warward, ribbon-crossed.
“Hast clapped thy chest-nest, lad?” she kvelled—
Old Maired in knitted peal and woe;
The hingey past leant, sighed, re-shelled
And back the cheru-chest did go.

The loft, once twee, now unplumed light—
And ceil-cracks chortled in good-part;
He bore the enlarged heartdown home,
Wood-songed and nevermore apart.
He left the room with whiffled step,
Where timbre-softened trunk lay mild—
O cedar chest of Ulberwick,
You mammoth-keeper of the child!
label: high
